title: pyrootmemo
text:
My colleague Gerrit J. Meijer and I developed this project to help users to estimate contribution of roots to the shear strength of soil using various models. The documentation is structured to provide a comprehensive guide to using the library, including installation, quickstart, theoretical background, and detailed explanations of the available models. pyrootmemo is designed using Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) principles, making it easy to extend and customize for your specific needs.

Visit our github repo to see further details: github.com/rootmemo/pyrootmemo
Read the documentation on pyrootmemo.readthedocs.io
Do you want to contribute? See our Contribution guidelines

title: Milestone 1
text:
Make Plots
We shall now make a simple plot. Note that by using the quarto option #| code-fold: true , we can hide the code that is used to make the plot and allow it to be expanded as shown below.


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
x = np.linspace(0, 2, 100)  # Sample data.

plt.figure()
plt.plot(x, x, label='linear')  # Plot some data on the (implicit) axes.
plt.plot(x, x**2, label='quadratic')  # etc.
plt.plot(x, x**3, label='cubic')
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('y')
plt.title("Simple Plot")
plt.legend()
plt.show()

title: Anil Yildiz, Dr. sc.
text:
Welcome
I am working as a senior researcher and deputy director of Chair of Methods for Model-Development in Computational Engineering (MBD) leading the research group Engineering Climate Change Response. My research interests centre around geohazards, but range from soil-plant-atmosphere interactions to shallow landslides. I am conducting research on computational, surrogate and data-driven modelling of gravitional mass flows. I am very interested in reproducible workflows, metadata extraction, data-integrated modelling workflows and executable publications.
